ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE CONVENTION AND EXHIBITION CENTRES


    1. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Trade and Industry how will Singapore's convention and exhibition centres be affected by the recently completed multi-million dollar convention and exhibition hall in Yogjakarta.

    The Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the S$10 million Jogja Expo Centre in Yogjakarta was opened last year. We understand that its main purpose is to provide a platform for small and medium-sized enterprises, especially vendors of arts and craft, to showcase and sell their products. Given the richness and diversity of Indonesian products in this area, such a centre is important in promoting commerce. As its primary focus is on domestic trade

Column: 2281

fairs and conventions, the Jogja Expo Centre will complement rather than compete with Singapore, which is targeting mainly international exhibitions and conventions.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, it was reported in the newspapers on 9th December that Yogjakarta intends to establish some direct trade routes with the region. Because of its landlocked nature in the past, it had always been operating through Bali, Jakarta and Medan. One of the options is to establish direct trade routes with Singapore. In view of this, what is Singapore's position with regard to this intention on the part of Yogjakarta?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Mdm Ho is quite right about Yogjakarta's intention to boost its role in the region. They are trying to promote themselves as a cultural, educational and tourism hub to compete with Bali and other centres of attraction in Indonesia. We see this as complementary with us. The more links we have to the region, the better. It enhances our role and we also want the various centres of commerce in Indonesia to succeed. So, it is complementary.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: It is also understood that Yogjakarta is known to be a nest for fundamental Islam in this part of the world. In view of its intention to establish direct trade links via Singapore, how would this impact our security and competition in Singapore?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: We have trade links with all parts of the world. We have trade links with parts of the world which are politically stable as well as those that are politically complex. I do not think that we should be distracted from providing this connectivity where there is business to be done. If there is a case for security measures, when it comes to relationships with particular cities or countries, that would be undertaken in a sensible fashion. But it should not distract us from being able to conduct trade and boost commerce with all countries in the world.

SENNETT ESTATE
(Upgrading)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong -

    2. To ask the Minister for National Development whether the recent decision to upgrade Sennett Estate is based on the Estate's eligibility or is it a result of the promise made by the Prime Minister in the last General Election.

    Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang (Marine Parade): Question No. 2, Sir.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the decision to upgrade Sennett Estate is based on the eligibility of the estate as well as the Prime Minister's promise made at the last General Election. All private estates which apply for upgrading under the Estate Upgrading Programme will be ranked and selected based on factors such as the age and condition of the estate, the level of community bonding and the level of support for the programme. At the last General Election, the Prime Minister promised that Sennett Estate would be considered for upgrading if residents showed that they supported the programme offered by the PAP candidate for Potong Pasir. After the General Election, both candidates for Potong Pasir publicly affirmed that the majority of Sennett Estate residents had given their votes to the PAP.

    Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang: Can the Minister of State please elaborate on the extent of upgrading that is going to be provided?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Sir, the details of the upgrading for Sennett Estate are still being worked out. I think it would be premature for me to make any definitive statement to that effect.

THREAT OF TERRORISM
(Motion)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [20th January 2003],

Column: 2283



    "That this House (a) acknowledges that the terrorist threat to Singapore is real and serious; (b) supports the firm actions the Government has taken against the threat to the security of Singapore posed by the Jemaah Islamiyah group and other militant and extremist groups in the region; and (c) endorses the recommendations put forth in the White Paper on The Jemaah Islamiyah Arrests and the Threat of Terrorism, contained in Paper Cmd. 2 of 2003, to counter the terrorist threat by (i) enhancing the security measures; (ii) policing the spread of terrorist and extremist ideology; and (iii) strengthening our social cohesion and religious harmony.". - [Mr Wong Kan Seng].

    Question again proposed.

    Mrs Fang Ai Lian (Nominated Member): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you for accommodating me. I, too, would like to support the motion.

    Indeed, it is very disturbing to read the contents of the White Paper and how it would affect Singapore. So, I fully agree with the comments made by the Government to respond in a robust manner, and that we should indeed respond to a threat which will really threaten our national security.

    Much has been said by many speakers about how Singaporeans ought to respond to this threat by groups such as the JI. I do not wish to cover the same grounds because, by and large, I agree with all of the comments made. But I would like to make a few comments from just one single aspect, and that is from my perspective as an employer and as a corporate citizen.

    From all the speeches made, we can see that it is important to respond to the threat from two somewhat opposing ways. One is that we have to be extra-vigilant. We cannot allow potential threats to be diminished or left unchecked. But, on the other hand, we cannot allow ourselves to become overly cautious or overly suspicious about Muslims in general. Because this would then result in a great divide in our society, and our society is just not about Singapore alone. It is also about our Muslim neighbours. So, if we do not approach the issue in a way that it should be sensibly approached, we can provide a very fertile soil for extremists to exploit the situation and to make political capital out of a very

Column: 2284

sensitive situation just by simply alleging discrimination against a particular racial or religious group.

    As employers, we face these concerns. We are in a much more precarious situation compared to the man-in-the-street. Because when an individual decides to take an overly suspicious stance with his Muslim neighbour, we can probably stop at that. But this is not one man with tremendous irrational fears. But when employers and corporates behave that way or have that sort of feeling, then the consequences, indeed, can be magnified many times over, and it would then not be unreasonable for the Muslim community to think that they have been disenfranchised and marginalised, and for them to feel discouraged and depressed.

    Therefore, as an employer, I would like to call on fellow employers to make that special effort to ensure, and to be seen to be ensuring, a level playing field in terms of employment and treatment of our Muslim counterparts. When the JI paper was first presented, a number of employer organisations indeed came out to affirm the importance of abiding by the principles of meritocracy to ensure that job applicants are judged solely based on qualifications, experience and also on other objective measures. This is very important. Not only must we be doing this, we must also be seen to be doing this. So our employment processes and our business dealings with our Muslim counterparts must be utterly transparent. And this is even more important, given the fact that we have a somewhat high unemployment situation where we get hundreds of applicants per job, and it is so easy to cry foul and allege discrimination against a particular grouping.

    On a practical note, as employers, it would be very difficult for us to sniff out potential terrorists. From the profiles of the arrested JI members, it would appear that they are very ordinary folks. So, it would take no less than the ISD to identify them and to round them up. From a statistical point of view, we are also talking about small numbers against a very large group of Muslim citizens. Therefore, the

Column: 2285

statistical chance of letting a terrorist through our organisation, I think, is also quite low and remote.

    My point here is that, on the part of employers, there is no need to develop elaborate processes to sniff out so-called potential terrorists. But what is important for us to do, as I said earlier on, is to make that special effort to be fair, and to be seen to be fair, in our treatment of our Muslim employees. We must simply not let the situation get out of hand. Because if we do so, we might have to face up to demands for positive discrimination for groups, which feel they have been treated or discriminated against, for their particular problems to be specifically addressed. This is the case in the US when they have legislation specifically drawn up for minority groups and also for women. So, we do not want legislation to be enacted because it is cumbersome, and it is counter-productive. But, as employers, as corporate citizens, we have got to preserve that right against legislation and, therefore, we must do everything we can to be ever mindful that we are seen to be treating our Muslim counterparts as fairly as possible. Our Muslim community too, on their part, can also contribute to this mutual tolerance, respect and moderation, because we have a collective interest here. We have a collective interest about our well-being and our national security. Together, we have much to achieve, we can triumph.

    On that note, Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I too rise in support of the motion moved by the Minister for Home Affairs.

    I would like, as many others before me have done, to also applaud the Ministry of Home Affairs for initiating and publishing the comprehensive, frank and penetrating White Paper on the historical existence and the clandestine activities of the Jemaah Islamiyah, leading to the arrest of several of their members and also highlighting the seriousness of the threat of terrorism Singapore faces.

Column: 2286



    In particular, I am heartened by the fact that what initially appeared as scepticism among certain quarters in resurfacing the Jemaah Islamiyah issue by way of debating the published White Paper in this House has now turned into a positive and lively public debate. I believe it has created greater public awareness and stimulated intense discussion among Singaporeans of all races. What is important is the fact that Singaporeans are now more wary that the threat of terrorism is a serious matter and driven primarily by global forces beyond our shores. Discussing and debating this sensitive issue in such an open manner, both publicly and in this House, again sends the signal to the world that not only are we maturing as a society but also presents us the opportunity to desensitise this issue, which affects the Malay/Muslim community, and consolidates Singapore's fortification against terrorism. It helps focus it into a Singaporean problem rather than just that of a particular community.

    Since the uncovering of the JI's clandestine activities, the Government has taken many firm steps such as implementing defensive security measures at key installations and buildings, and tightening border controls. Recognising that terrorism world-wide is funded by money-laundering operations, Parliament has also given the mandate to criminalise terrorist funding and that this new law is coming into effect later this month.

    I believe this is integral in the wide range of initiatives being taken to combat terrorism. Policing and crippling the flow of funds to and from illegitimate sources is necessary to prevent another potential Bali-like incident where the terrorists feel pressured and were compelled to do something, because the funds were in their hands to conduct such extremist acts. In these aspects, we must remain at least one but, preferably, several steps ahead of the terrorists.

    But, Sir, owing to the distinctive religious dimension in today's terrorism, tackling this danger by means of just defensive security measures is not adequate. A more holistic dual track approach encompassing hard and soft measures is

Column: 2287

necessary to achieve overall effectiveness in stamping out terrorism. According to terrorism expert, Dr Bruce Hoffman, the defeating of the Al-Qaeda requires pinpointing the "inner logic" that "motivates terrorists and animates terrorism". The same holds true for the JI and other religiously-driven extremist and militant organisations.

    Since the JI issue afflicts the Muslim community, it is encouraging to note that the Malay/Muslim community, religious and mosque leaders have come out strongly in support of the White Paper and condemning the JI and its extremist agenda, and also acknowledging that such groups are a menace to our society. Many measures have also been proposed to check and prevent the emergence of such groups again in the future. Measures ranging from taking stock of the curriculum of Islamic religious education, registering qualified asatizahs, or religious teachers, to sanctioning foreign religious speakers have been mentioned by the Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs yesterday, and also by several of my Malay colleagues in this House who have spoken earlier. These are either already implemented or are being seriously considered for implementation.

    However, Sir, while such measures are necessary and important, I believe that the long run measure should be to ensure that the Muslim community is equipped with a sound and rational knowledge of Islam as well as an appreciation of the other major religions in our country, in consideration of the multi-racial and multi-religious context within which we all live. A proper knowledge of Islam will help in preventing the infection of deviant ideas from taking root among Muslims here. Knowledge of other religions would help in enhancing the understanding and the preservation of harmony among the various racial groups.

    Two Sundays ago, my constituency's IRCC organised a visit to the various places of worship within the Pasir Ris area. We started with the Pentacost Methodist Church where, after a briefing of the history of the church and its activities, we

Column: 2288

were invited to join in the service. I was subsequently surprised in being called upon to address the congregation and was later told that I was the first Muslim to have done so. I told them that singing hymns and saying the Lord's prayer was nothing new to me, as I attended Presbyterian High, a missionary school during my secondary school days, and yet I am still very much a Muslim today. We all laughed through it.

    Last year, in May, while being in the United States, I had the opportunity to join in a community gathering near the hotel where I was put up. A pastor generously approached a black Muslim attendee to start the meeting with a prayer. He graciously replied by requesting the pastor to open with the Lord's prayer. After several enthusiastic echoes of "Amen" from all, the Muslim community leader lamented that this too was no different from the prayer of Muslims! It is apparent that communities, wherever they now live in the world, are generally making efforts to bridge the gaps of understanding between Muslims and non-Muslims, and especially so since after the 9/11 unfortunate event in 2001.

    Our Chinese majority non-Muslims, whether Buddhists, Christians or Taoists, should also reciprocate by making an effort to understand and know more about true Islam which is truly a religion of peace, but which has regrettably been subjected to extreme misinterpretations by irresponsible Muslims and non-Muslims to wholly advance their personal agenda. The Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs, Dr Yaacob, again yesterday and also several other Malay colleagues of mine have all elaborated on the subject of Islam at length in their speeches in this House over the last two days.

    I would like to thank all my non-Muslim colleagues who have spoken so eloquently in support of the need for and the benefit of more public education on the various religious and cultural practices of the racial groups here and also the need to strengthen the links between our key ethnic groups. Only through such initiatives and concerted action of greater

Column: 2289

communication and involvement with each other could we achieve better understanding, which would lead to a stronger bond and trust between the major races in Singapore. We should capitalise on the current positive mood and push for attitudinal change among all Singaporeans, Muslims or non-Muslims, to take the issue of strengthening harmony and social integration more seriously than ever.

    In regard to the concern of potential discrimination at the workplace, it is heartening that there is a strong call among workers of different races and religions to uphold the principle of meritocracy. I also applaud the effort of NTUC, the Singapore National Employers' Federation and the Singapore Business Federation to jointly craft a 'code of responsible employment practices' which recommended, among others, to adopt consistent and objective selection criteria for employment and to avoid discriminatory rules in considering promotion and advancement opportunities.

    I would like to call upon employers of large and small companies, MNCs or local SMEs, as Mrs Fang Ai Lian has also done so a moment ago, to continue to adopt such fair and equal opportunity employment practices as we have done so all this while. Discriminating and sidelining Malay/Muslims in jobs if they could perform just as well as any other Singaporean would not augur well for our society. As Dr Yaacob, Dr Wang Kai Yuen and several others have pointed out, many Malay Singaporeans have been performing better and excelling in various fields. Unless equal opportunities - and I would like to stress here, equal opportunities on the basis of our time-tested meritocratic principles are created for them to progress alongside other Singaporeans - the community will be denied of role models to catalyse further progress. It is a known fact that societies and communities blessed with successful role models develop greater confidence to undertake more difficult challenges in every facet of life and tend to progress faster. When this happens, the entire

Column: 2290

society benefits from it. As the saying goes, success breeds success.

    On the other hand, it has to be borne in mind that a Malay community which is discriminated against and denied of opportunities, in spite of putting in best efforts, will degenerate and turn into a disgruntled community. Over time, if not managed, an underclass, in the sense of groups who have lost all hope and dropped out from Singapore's mainstream society, will emerge. I do not think I need to describe what such a scenario would mean to Singapore.

    I know the Government would never allow the emergence of an underclass in our country. But I think it is important that we bring this perspective in the context of the current discussion.

    Sir, in Dr Wang Kai Yuen's speech in this House yesterday, he noted that many Muslims could not reconcile themselves that the JI members are bad Muslims and were just carrying out their Muslim duties when they joined the JI organisation in defence of Islam. As a matter of further clarification, Sir, it is important to note that the JI members were well aware of what they were going into when they decided to be a part of the JI. As noted in the White Paper, they were willing participants and well immersed in extremist activities long before the September 11 incident and their subsequent arrests. Their plans to attack targets in Singapore go back to the mid-1990s and intensified after September 11, 2001. Considering also the above-average education that most of the JI detainees have, it is imperative for our Singaporean Muslims to know and are convinced that the JI members know exactly what they were getting into and the potential devastation they would have caused, should their plans be successfully executed. Both Muslims and non-Muslims would have been victims of their aggressive acts.

    In conclusion, Sir, while the White Paper focuses on the JI perpetrating terrorism under the cloak of the Islamic faith, it must also be borne in mind that terrorism is,

Column: 2291

by no means, bounded by religion. The Oklahama City bombing by Timothy McVeigh and the sarin gas attack in underground subways by the Aum cult in Japan are some terror acts that come to mind. As such, Singaporeans must always be on guard against not only religious but also other forms of extremism to help the Government and, for that matter, ourselves, as Singaporeans, to protect lives and property, and preserve the inter-ethnic harmony that we have painstakingly built since our independence. The conclusion of the White Paper is apt in reminding us that, given the nature of the terrorist threat we face today, preservation of harmony is paramount to ensuring Singapore's continued well-being.

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, for letting me speak. Today's debate is important because we are discussing a topic that has affected and will continue to affect the lives of all Singaporeans.

    For 30-odd years, we have enjoyed peace and prosperity. Then came September 11 which shook the whole world. To many Singaporeans, this tragedy opens the eyes of many to the dangers that could fall upon them. This fear was confirmed when we discovered a terrorist group and arrested 15 members of this radical Islamic group, Jemaah Islamiyah, in December 2001. They had very sinister motives, including bombings of foreign embassies and even local targets, like Yishun MRT Station. Then in August 2002, ISD arrested another 21 persons.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the message is very clear. We better get to understand and expose the terrorist network and the dangers they pose before our citizens get hurt or killed. Judging from the information being covered and linking this with other countries' findings, this is going to last a very, very long time. Therefore, this White Paper is timely. Because of the in-depth discussion on the terrorist operations and the people involved, this White Paper is a must read for all who cherish this place. It provides an important source of information and understanding for the average citizen, who must know, by now,

Column: 2292

how close we were to tragic happenings of the kind seen at Bali where more than 200 lives were lost. They will better appreciate why we took such swift actions against these anti-national elements.

    The truth of the matter is that the terrorists are at our doorsteps. We must do our utmost to prevent them from spreading their network, and this is where every citizen counts in our approach to block, frustrate, and to check their activities and movements. We must remember our security is under attack, and unless our citizens show their determination and resolve to protect what we have built up over the years, we may suffer severe damages to lives and targets.

    The White Paper showed clearly the targets these people are gunning - MRT stations, shopping and crowded places, places of worship, airports, and many soft targets - where civilian casualties will be high. They are not worried about killing Muslims, Christians, Hindus and foreigners. To them the ideology comes first. They want to create chaos - security, racial, religious, social and economic chaos - preventing investors to come, and disrupting and destroying the infrastructures we built. This is a national issue. And all races must band together and not let these anti-national elements break us apart. We have come this far through working together and enjoying the benefits of strong economic growth, good education, medical care, good housing, and security. We walk the streets safely. Do not let these be taken away. These are all worth fighting for, and dying for. We must not give these up easily by allowing these people to throw a spanner into our society and make our Chinese and Indian communities distrust the Malay community, just because they happen to embrace Islam.

    The media, television, radio and newspapers have put Muslims in the limelight because of events like September 11, and the carnage at Bali. Our Malay community, being Muslims, have been drawn into this. Moreover, of late, our Malays have become more pious and religious. Their dressing and social behaviour have also

Column: 2293

changed. There is nothing wrong in being pious. However, these changes and trends have made the Chinese and Indians colour their attitudes towards them. I do not think this is racial in nature. I blame this on human nature's association of thoughts, trends and events, that have made them feel this way. I think this attititudinal change happens everywhere. We have seen it happening in the United States, Australia, Britain, and even in Belgium in a place called Antwerp. But we must take swift action not to allow this to sow seeds of distrust.

    Over the years since independence, at the ground level, each community has contributed to the closely-knit society of multi-racial living and that probably helps a great deal during such trying times. However, we must never take things for granted. We must move forward and continue to work on this foundation, reinforcing the need to live together harmoniously, and giving assurances and words of comfort to each community.

    Thus, the many statements of support from the Malay community, especially outsiders, help to give strong signals of assurances to the non-Muslim communities, that the JI is the work of a minority of Muslims, and that the majority of Malays are against their actions and wrong-doings. Moderate Malay leaders must not let the extremist minority call the agenda. Non-Muslims watch the reactions of our Malay community towards this White Paper because non-Muslims want assurances, and investors also want assurances. Yesterday, my colleague, Ahmad Khalis, told this House that more than 127 Malay organisations have openly come out to support the Government's action and condemned the JI. This is the most significant stand and speaks well for the Malay leadership.

    So when I read the headline article on 14th January, "Let's All Back JI White Paper - Urges the leader of Khatijah Mosque", I see it as a good and clear signal. Other organisations, like Pergas, the Singapore Islamic Scholars and Religious Teachers Association, have come

Column: 2294

out in support. The latest MUIS' statement on the correct practice of Muslims is most welcomed. This, coupled with my Malay parliamentary colleagues' press statement, condemning the JI and its extremist agenda, augurs well for all of us, especially the non-Muslims and those who want to invest here.

of the present circumstances. The vetting of foreign religious leaders, be they Muslims, Christians, Hindus, must be careful and discriminating. and professional. For those few who practise discrimination, I think they should be educated and corrected. The Singapore Business Federation and NTUC will have a big role to play in this area.

    Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (Sembawang): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate on this very important matter facing us.

    Indeed, the issues before us are multi-faceted. On the one hand, we are facing a serious threat to our internal security. On the other hand, we are faced with the philosophical issue of religion and religiosity amidst rising global religious revivalism. Yet, on another front we are challenged to ensure that our social cohesion remains strong and intact. All these, with the background of increased globalisation and economic uncertainty, certainly not the best of times, but persevere we must, to ensure the continued survival of the generations to come.

    The challenge for speakers on the last day of such a debate is always to say what has not already been said - it is indeed a challenge. Much has been said about the damage that terrorist acts will do to any society. We have seen the devastation of the irresponsible acts of September 11 and October 12, not to mention the many more by Al-Qaeda and the JI. Sir, the extent of terrorist acts that have been linked to the JI has been documented in a report entitled, "Indonesia's Terrorist Network: How Jemaah Islamiyah Works", prepared by the International Crisis Group (ICG). priests in 11 cities. Nineteen people were killed and some 120 wounded. These are very serious attacks planned by people who have no qualms about taking the lives of innocent people. These are the people whom we are talking about today. Singaporeans cannot take the threat lightly.

The Minister for Defence has already said that defence spending for this year will be increased. There has been a visible increase in the number of visitors to places of worship like mosques, churches and temples, in the name of improving mutual understanding and tolerance. Column: 2301

ensuring our own security? We are not expected to be vigilant or to track every suspected character that lives in our midst. But we can ensure that we actively invest in our social relationships such that we are comfortable and confident of the level of trust that we have with each other, with the people who live around us. For all those Singaporeans out there who are not activists or have not participated in grassroots activities, what is your role in ensuring and strengthening our social bonds? More generally, have we invested sufficiently in our social relationships with the people around us? At the most micro level, do we know our neighbours well enough? These questions had been raised yesterday. How many neighbours who live in the same block of an HDB flat does the average Singaporean know? What about within the same RC zone?

    Why are these questions important? Our housing policy ensures that we live among the different ethnic groups. The level of trust that we have of the people around us will ensure that our social cohesion remains strong. It will also act as a deterrence for individuals to get involved in acts that will hurt the people that are close and mean something to them.

    Sir, the psychological profile of the JI members, as reported in the White Paper, noted that they had high level of loneliness. Perhaps they may also not be close to their extended network, let alone their neighbours. The point I am making, Sir, is that social networking is an active process that requires effort and time. We need to reflect on the value we place on such relationships and act upon it.

    We have often heard the common response of the lack of time as a reason for not participating in grassroots-organised activities. Many will also say they do not even have time to interact with their neighbours. If this is true, we have to ask ourselves: where will this lead us to in the long run? If there is one thing that we can learn from this JI episode it is that we can no longer take our social relationships for

Column: 2302

granted. We need to consciously find time and invest in these relationships.

    What is also more critical is the inter-ethnic relations between neighbours. What is the current level of inter-ethnic relations in our neighbourhoods? The housing policy has been in place for many years now. But anecdotal evidence, however, suggests that relationship is, at best, superficial. The grassroots organisations can do their part in organising activities that will facilitate interaction. But if we do not embrace the value, we will continue having the same converted individuals attend those functions. Perhaps, grassroots organisations should consider reducing the geographical focus of their activities to a smaller number of blocks of flats to encourage more micro-level interaction between neighbours. This is not to micro-manage relationships between neighbours but to facilitate their interaction, knowing how critical such relationships are in ensuring a continued level of trust amongst residents. We have heard anecdotal incidences of people not wanting to be in the same lift with members of other ethnic groups following the news of the JI arrests last year. Such unwanted incidences can be avoided if neighbours really know and trust one another. Cumulatively, it will ensure a higher level of trust between people.

    Sir, the White Paper is not only a call for Singaporeans to wake up to the impending danger that is lurking outside our doorsteps. It is also a gentle reminder for us to reflect within ourselves some of the fundamental values that we uphold. Are we willing to leave our comfort zones and be part of the larger network? The bottom-line goes back to Singaporeans. Do they feel compelled enough to answer this call or are they comfortably living within the four walls of their own homes?

    The White Paper also raises the important, though rather abstract, issue of religion and religiosity. It is indeed complex - for one it is supposed to be a private and individual affair - but at the same time, it has implications for a larger community. Indeed, we used to think of religion as being part of a private space of

Column: 2303

the individual and have left it to that space. We separate religion from the affairs of the state precisely because we know the complications that will arise if we did otherwise, especially in a multi-religious society like ours.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the complexity of religion cannot be sufficiently underscored. In any religion, there exist fundamental doctrines, often times, manifested in various forms. Varying behavioural manifestations of followers are used as indicators of variations in the interpretations of these doctrines. No religious community is spared from dealing with such complexities. The complexity is acknowledged by social scientists who study religiosity. As a psychological construct, these scientists agree that religiosity is a multi-dimensional phenomenon. They view religiosity as more than just a behavioural manifestation of the religion. It includes both intrinsic and extrinsic commitments to the religion. It is thus even more difficult for those outside any community to comprehend that very complexity.

    Today, the Muslim community is put on the spotlight and its members have struggled to explain variations that exist within the community itself. Some have said that the doctrines are there and it is the individual's personal choice to follow for at the end of the day, it is between him and his Creator, while others believe it is their duty to ensure that those who steer away are brought back to the right path. For example, what makes a wife beater, who piously prays five times a day but works irregularly and does not support the family financially, more or less of a Muslim, compared to a non-tudung wearing single mother who works hard and struggles to provide food on the table for her children? may translate into prejudices and prejudiced behaviours. To facilitate interactions, especially cross-culturally, we should remain non-judgmental and learn to accept the person who he or she is.

The fervent encouragement to draw out both Muslims and non-Muslims to engage in open dialogues to discuss their fears, suspicions and aspirations is a necessary phase in the healing process.

Column: 2308

and JI is a war fought by all Singaporeans. We have to be aware of the threat terrorism poses, the need to be vigilant and how as a people we must work through our differences to foster closer ties so as to prevent any cleavage in our social fabric caused by those with ulterior motives.

Column: 2309

Muslim fraternity feels that they are under scrutiny, that they are being blocked out of many opportunities in getting a job, or a promotion.

Column: 2310

mindset for the worst so that when the worst does occur, we know what to do.

    Foremost in the minds of many Singaporeans is the question: why is it that it has taken the Government so long to present the facts to the public? Column: 2311

arrests, the JI activities had elicited a different response from the Muslim community. The Muslim community has openly condemned the JI agenda. Such a stand taken by the Muslim community has given much reassurance to the other racial groups of the allegiance of our Muslim brothers and sisters to Singapore as a nation and fellow Singaporeans.

Column: 2312

that the host would accord to them. We know that familiarity breeds contempt, and once you are used to one another, you do away with formalities and niceties.

    Reflecting on her comment further, I asked myself if there is a need to revisit our often take-for-granted attitude. When there is a patch in a relationship to be mended, it is good to be aware of the need to re-establish these formalities and niceties, as such efforts reassure the desire to want to work out positive outcomes. So, perhaps, social groupings should begin some refresher programmes on inter-relationship skills.

    Perhaps the grassroots organisations should start a Conversation series in small groupings of not more than 30, to encourage more sharing among the multi-racial groupings.

    We should also dispel suspicion and avoid criticism when we observe differences in practices. For example, we should not see it as wrong if a Muslim woman does not shake hands with her male colleague. She is behaving in a proper manner as prescribed by her faith. We should not be suspicious but be respectful of that. In fact, I was told that conservative Indian ladies too do not shake hands with men. We should take heart that we are far-removed from really knowing the practices of other races and religions.

    Nonetheless, we must have a ready mindset to embrace and learn from the experiences of others. For example, the Sikh communities in the US had stepped forward to talk about their faith in the light of racial attacks after 9/11. All Singaporeans could similarly do more of this.

    This bottom-up approach is the responsibility at the individual level and must be the way to move forward, complementing the top-down approach as seen in the setting-up of IRCCs.

    Sir, many Singaporeans, including Members of this Chamber, feel that the way to move ahead is not to have more control and legislation, but to prevent

Column: 2313

economic and social disenfranchisement among some minorities, which might give rise to more would-be terrorists. I was told that many Malay taxi drivers have been relating the sad fate of fellow Muslims finding a job, due to racial discrimination.

    On this, I would like to share that statistics from the Ministry of Manpower showed a "more or less" equal distribution of the unemployed among the Malays, Chinese and Indians. Very often, it is a question of competencies, not race, that mattered in job selection. However, we have to note that the perception of disenfranchisement, which might be contrary to reality, takes on a dose of reality itself when it is repeated enough. And there will always be people who wish to exploit this gap between perception and reality. We need to remind employers to be more open and transparent in their selection and hiring practices.

    Next, I would like to touch on managing inter-racial harmony at the workplace and creating more awareness in the institutions of learning on the White Paper.

    Sir, the White Paper is silent on how relationship at the workplace ought to be managed. Whilst I understand that employers and union leaders are being briefed on the White Paper, I am concerned that the operational people-managers and informal leaders at the workplace to-date have not received proper guidance on how to deal with sensitivities concerning our multi-racial workforce.

    The casual approach towards the terrorist threat adopted at work so far has resulted in many at the workplace taking the situation lightly. This is clearly demonstrated by the few reported incidents of bomb hoax at workplace.

    Another disturbing observation is that some individuals at the workplace are taking political advantage of the situation for their short-term agenda. We are hearing more allegations of racial discrimination in recruitment and promotion

Column: 2314

exercises. This gets picked up and, rightly or wrongly, the sympathies go to the aggrieved party.

    Sir, here is where we want both employers and union leaders to play their part to remind informal leaders at workplace to be quick to dispel such allusions.

    Sir, I speak this from a personal experience. Not too long ago, a colleague at work informed me of an incident with the mother of a young Muslim recruit for the job of an apprentice. She came to the workplace to sign the Training bond as a guarantor for her son. She informed the executive attending to her, that her son would not be able to perform work every Friday from 12 noon to 3 pm because of prayers. In response, my colleague advised that the job could not accommodate a long break of three hours and that it would be good for her son to rethink about the job.

    Sir, we have to acknowledge that the workplace is common ground for all. It is sometimes difficult for employers to draw a line between accommodating employees' requirements and getting the job done. This is not about marginalising the minority race, but the need to preserve common identity in a common place.

    Sir, it is important for the community at large to know that selection and promotion are guided by criteria, and if applicants do not qualify, it is because they have not met with the criteria and not because of racial discrimination.

    Like my colleagues before me, I would like to comment on my hon. colleague, Mr Shanmugam's statement about "a small measure of affirmative action" to enable more Malays to occupy important posts. I am happy to note that, in this instance, our system has been doing that for the latter, starting from the highest office in Singapore. We had a Malay President in Yusof Ishak. There are also other top positions in both the private and Government sectors held by Malays.

    In support of Dr Tan Cheng Bock's rejection of the suggestion of marginalisation

Column: 2315

of Muslims, I would like to point out here that everything else being equal, it is important that, in the final analysis, when picking a candidate for a position, it goes beyond considerations of meritocracy. In reality, factors that align the affinity of the candidate to the job and the people around are just as important.

    Sir, in connection with promoting inter-racial harmony at the workplace, I would like to propose for a series of awareness programmes on how to deal with the sensitivities of the multi-racial workforce at the workplace. In fact, to begin with, I am proposing to incorporate a Certificate and Diploma module on inter-racial relationship in Human Resource and Industrial Relations programmes so that people-managers, union leaders and, subsequently, the workforce, will acquire the necessary knowledge and skills to deal with one another more sensitively.

    Further, in order to make these programmes accessible, I hope that the Skills Development Fund (SDF) would consider giving these programmes the necessary funding so that companies will be more ready to send their employees. More importantly, we want to bring home the point that 9/11 and the subsequent arrests of the JI members have certainly changed our modus operandi at work. And multi-racial relationship management must become the core curriculum at the workplace.

    Besides the workplace, we should also look at the schools, JCs and tertiary institutions. The terrorist issue and threat of the JI are here to stay. The 3Gs will be living with this threat and all the related sensitivities. This is a special group that we must garner to understand and appreciate what the JI and terrorist threats are all about.

    I would urge for schools to initiate discussion on the White Paper. It needs special study in the GP curriculum. With a good appreciation of the complexities of the matter, our 3Gs would be better prepared to deal with the issues that threaten us.

Column: 2316



    Finally, going forward. We should no longer be moaning over whose responsibility it is to drive the unity of Singaporeans, but rather as Singaporeans, how and what should we do to ensure the strengthening of our social fabric.

    Now that we have boldly and clearly clarified that Malay/Muslims are not marginalised, we must make every effort to erase such notions and talks. Efforts must come from both Muslims and non-Muslims. We could learn from the constant mutual assurances between the Muslims and non-Muslims in the UK. We should also heed the words of US President George Bush, "Islam is a religion we accept, but not Al-Qaeda".

    And, Sir, similarly, we should also heed these words. If an individual is not promoted to a higher position, or selected for a post, it is because he did not meet the criteria needed for the post, and not because of race.

    On this note, I support the motion.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion standing in the name of the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Wong Kan Seng.

    Sir, the White Paper clearly sets out the history and the nature of the threat of terrorism in Singapore. It also recommends bold initiatives to deal with this threat. Many of us have assumed that terrorist activities in Singapore only started in 2001, after the September 11 attack on the World Trade Center and that it has ended with the recent arrests of the JI activists. The White Paper shows us otherwise. Terrorism in Singapore dates back a long way and it is far from being eliminated. It is a deep-rooted problem. It threatens the stability and security of our society. It needs to be addressed thoroughly and seriously. On the other extreme, there are also people who are paranoid and see terrorists everywhere. There is no need to over-react and, as a result, strain inter-relations. We need to have a balanced approach. The White Paper is, therefore, a timely document that

Column: 2317

provides some guidelines for dealing with this issue. It also reminds us that terrorism is a problem for all Singaporeans. Government's efforts alone will not be enough. We must work together to deal with it as a united people

    I agree with the three key recommendations set out in the paper, ie, to enhance security measures, to police the threat of terrorism and to strengthen social cohesion and religious harmony. These are the three pillars of our counter-terrorism strategy. I would like to share some of my views and suggestions in this respect.

    Firstly, I agree with Mdm Ho Geok Choo that we must be prepared. We must prepare our people for the eventuality of an actual terrorist attack in Singapore. Sir, I am fully confident of the effectiveness of our security measures and the capability of our security agencies to manage and minimise the terrorist risks. However, we must not and cannot afford to be complacent. We must recognise that there is a possibility, remote as it may be, that a terrorist incident could actually happen in Singapore. As documents released recently by the Ministry of Home Affairs have shown, had we not caught the JI terrorists in time, a major incident could have taken place. If and when this happens, the psychological impact on our people could far outstrip the physical impact of the incident. More importantly, it could create a rift among Singaporeans of different races and religions. It could threaten the cohesiveness of our society. The multi-racial and multi-religious society we have so painstakingly built over the last 30 years could easily be destroyed overnight. If this happens, the terrorists would have achieved their objective of destabilising the country.

    Therefore, I feel that other than enhancing physical security measures, we need to also prepare our people psychologically in the event that an incident does happen. To do this, I would like to urge the Ministry of Home Affairs to consider a public education programme aimed at informing our people what they ought to do

Column: 2318

and what they ought not to do in such eventualities. This is no different from our effort to prepare our people in Total Defence. The recent bomb hoax at Holland Village is an example of how an ill-informed public may be used to propagate damaging rumours that may cause panic among Singaporeans. Therefore, being well-informed is a crucial element of our preparedness against terrorist attacks. For example, we must constantly remind our people that should an incident happen, they should not panic and should not jump to conclusions prematurely. We should also remind them not to aid in propagating unverified rumours or to inform the authorities when they become aware of such rumours. Of course, this needs to be done carefully so as not to create unnecessary fear among our people. The key is to let them know what to expect and what is expected of them. This way, they would be psychologically prepared and would not be caught by surprise. The impact of any incident can then be better managed.

    Secondly, we need to strengthen the resilience of our people, especially the younger generation, against distorted teachings. The White Paper showed that among those arrested, all, except two, are of average or above average intelligence. They are not ignorant or destitute. They are fully aware of their actions and deadly serious about their missions. What disturbs me most is the ability of the terrorist network to attract intelligent people and sometimes respectable members of our society to join in their cause. Investigations showed that one of the recruitment techniques used by the JI network is through seemingly innocent religious classes. These classes have far-reaching influence on the impressionable minds of our younger Singaporeans. The teachers abuse the trust and betray the confidence of their students. Then they bind their recruits with threats of infidelity if they choose to leave their organisation. Such techniques are frightfully similar to those used by secret societies in the past. The long-term solution to terrorist threats is to find a way to disrupt their recruitment process. I believe that we must deal with the root of the issue. We must strengthen

Column: 2319

Singaporeans' resilience against recruitment efforts by the terrorist network and we must do so right from the start, among our younger Singaporeans.

    For this reason, I would like to suggest that we revise and update our school curriculum, for example, in the National Education Programme, to include issues relating to terrorism. Young Singaporeans must be taught the values of social cohesion and religious harmony. We must inculcate in them the basic values of mutual respect, mutual tolerance and mutual acceptance, regardless of race and religion. These values must be transformed from academic knowledge into a way of life for all Singaporeans. This way, when our younger Singaporeans come across teachings that do not conform to these basic values, they would then be able to question the basis of such teachings rather than being taken in by their emotional appeal. If they have been taught from young that it is wrong to take away lives, they will then have strong moral courage to resist the call to be part of a terrorist plan to kill innocent people. Therefore, I would like to urge the Ministry to work closely with the Ministry of Education to review our National Education Programme for this purpose.

    Thirdly, to strengthen religious harmony and foster greater mutual understanding and acceptance, we need to create more channels for communication among the various ethnic and religious groups. We cannot deny that many differences do exist among different religious and ethnic groups. To do so is being unrealistic. These differences are a result of our cultural heritage, our life experiences and our religious beliefs. Even within the same religious group, there are differences. I am a Christian. There are many different denominations within the Christian faith, with varying practices. Similarly, among the Chinese, there are also many different dialect groups - Teochew, Hokkien, Cantonese - some do not even talk to one another. However, on the other hand, there exist many similarities among these different groups. We share the same land, we share the same community, we share the same consequences if terrorism

Column: 2320

is allowed to grow in Singapore. Many of the potential conflicts stem from the lack of understanding of each other. Such misunderstanding, if not resolved, may eventually lead to distrust and eventually even animosity. To avoid this, we must acknowledge and accept the differences, but emphasise and build on the similarities.

    The setting up of the Inter-Racial Confidence Circles is a good start. Perhaps it would be useful for the Ministry of Community Development and Sports to consider organising more regular dialogues among the various groups at the national level. For example, we could consider an annual forum where leaders from various religious groups, as well as grassroots organisations, can gather to share their views and concerns. There could be open sessions as well as closed-door sessions. This will provide a platform for sensitive issues to be discussed and differences to be resolved in an orderly manner. It will also provide an opportunity for greater interaction among the leaders and, hopefully, this will lead to greater understanding and tolerance. This forum can also be used as a platform for the religious leaders to proclaim statements on their stand with regard to religious harmony. Such proclamation will serve as a constant reminder and a useful guide for the respective believers and followers. This forum can also become a symbol, an icon, of our commitment to social cohesion and racial harmony.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as we debate in this House how to tackle the threat of terrorism, we must not forget to recognise the good work put in by our security agencies. The Home Team, in particular, must be applauded for the effective intelligence they managed to gather and the swift and decisive actions that followed. It is through their relentless efforts that our homes are safe from the terrorists and we can all sleep soundly at night.

    On this note, Sir, I support the motion.

    Dr Chong Weng Chiew (Tanjong Pagar)(In Mandarin): Sir, I support the motion to

Column: 2321

endorse the recommendations proposed in the White Paper.

    Let me take this very serious topic in a more light-hearted manner. There were two families staying in the same block of flats and they did not interact between themselves, not even greeting each other when they met in the lift. One night, they were laughing, cheering and even held each other's hands in jubilation. Why? Because the Brazil soccer team, which they both supported, had won the World Cup. So, this common interest of theirs had bridged the gap between them.

    Now, let me touch on Part V of the White Paper on strengthening social cohesion and religious harmony. Over the years, the Government has been promoting religious harmony and as a result our people are living in harmony here in Singapore. In order to enhance our mutual understanding, we have to first learn and understand the differences among us, so that we would be able to accommodate, tolerate and live with each other. However, we are a multi-racial and multi-religious society. In order to enhance our cohesion, I think it is more important that we recognise our similarities than to emphasise our differences. There may be some competition between a hawker who sells apples and another who sells oranges, although the fruits they sell are quite different. But when someone advocates that it is better to eat vegetables than to eat fruits, I am sure the two fruit sellers will take a common stand and be united to argue otherwise.

    Apart from knowing and understanding the activities of the terrorists, I think we should use our common interest to enhance social cohesion. In our society, which is multi-racial and multi-religious, undoubtedly, we need to examine the differences between the various ethnic groups. But let us not forget that we have many things in common too! For example, we are all peace-loving people, we love our family, we love our country and, at the same time, we like to celebrate the various festivals. Whether you are a

Column: 2322

Christian, a Buddhist, a Hindu or a Muslim, you would pay a lot of attention to our respective ethnic and religious festivals. Just as we enjoy our reunion dinner on Chinese New Year's Eve, our fellow citizens of the other ethnic groups enjoy their respective festive celebration. However, the joy and happiness of these festivals are not confined to our own community only. I am sure you have this experience. During Hari Raya or Deepavali, you would have your Malay and Indian neighbours knocking at your door and offering you their traditional delicious kuehs and tid-bits. During the Chinese New Year festivities, they may also turn up at your flat to wish you Happy New Year and enjoy your new year goodies.

    The Christmas, Deepavali, Hari Raya and Chinese New Year light-ups are enjoyed by everyone, not just the individual community. I am sure all of us enjoy the festive mood. So, let us all live happily and peacefully together. There are differences between us, but let us look more at our similarities and less at our differences.

    Sir, I would like to suggest that we periodically and systematically create this kind of festive mood for our people. This is particularly useful in our multi-racial society.

    A foreign friend once told me that racial harmony in Singapore is not bad. But there seems to be a lack of communication and exchanges among the different cultures. Everyone seems to be living in their own quarters with no feeling for other communities. He may be a bit exaggerating, but it is true that quite a lot of our people are not showing interest and concern for the happenings in the other communities. We should try and encourage our people to seek and get into the common space among us. When we are faced with a cultural conflict, the more common points that we have discovered among us, the easier it would be to iron out the differences among us. So, if more opportunities are created for us to celebrate the various festivals together, it would be useful for us to resolve the

Column: 2323

differences, if any. We should learn to appreciate our counterparts in the other communities for their contributions to our nation building, and make it a point to show such appreciation. There could be more exchanges among the various cultures through various campaigns, get-togethers and even through the media. This will go a long way to enhance our social cohesion.

    Now, allow me to present my views on some of the other points in the White Paper. The organisation, planning and scheming of the terrorists right at our doorstep are real and serious. We should also have a long-term plan to counter such threat to our security. These terrorist activities, if successful, would impact not only our present generation, but also our future generations. So, we should bring this White Paper to the schools and include its contents to the school curriculum, according to the educational levels of the students. We could simplify the contents, even use cartoons or comics to teach our students, so that they would also know and understand the activities of the terrorists. One day, if we were to encounter an unfortunate incident in Singapore, then our people would be psychologically prepared to face them, and would have better understanding and tolerance among our various ethnic groups.

    Our Muslim compatriots in Singapore are just as peace loving as we are. We know that. Whether we are Malay, Indian or Chinese, we should trust one another and be united to fight our foreign intruders together. Otherwise, we would fall into the hands of our foreign intruders. Let us settle all our differences through our similarities and common space. Let us be united and build up our common aspirations, common wishes to settle the differences in our society so that we can have better mutual tolerance, thereby enhancing our social cohesion.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, after more than 30 speeches, I have no doubt that many in this House may inadvertently feel that they are suffering from an overdose of

Column: 2324

the debate on terrorism. Many of the statements made would, by now, have a familiar ring tone. Nonetheless, even at the risk of sounding like a broken record, I feel compelled to lend my voice to this chorus.

    Since as MP of a constituency, I feel duty-bound to voice my opinion and the views I have gathered from the residents of the community I represent on a subject of such critical importance. I therefore beg for your indulgence, Sir, and Members of this House as I give my response to the White Paper.

    Sir, the motion speaks of countering the terrorist threat in a three-fold manner, like by enhancing security measures, by policing the spread of terrorism and extremist ideology, and by strengthening our social cohesion and religious harmony. Like my parliamentary colleagues who have spoken before me, let me say, at the outset, that I support this motion because the consequences of terrorism, if left unchecked, are grave and unimaginable.

    Sir, I applaud the Government for having the moral courage to table this motion to debate the White Paper, even though it may once again put our Malay/Muslim community under the spotlight. It is unfortunate, but not unprecedented. Recall the anguish felt among the Chinese community at the chauvinistic tactics employed by Tang Liang Hong, two elections ago. Each time, issues like the Chinese Language, or Nantah, are brought up in its various forms, a raw nerve is struck.

    I, therefore, like many of my parliamentary colleagues before me, urge all Malay/Muslim Singaporeans to view this debate positively. It is not intended to highlight the Malay/Muslim community's deficiencies, but to air the issues in a calm and rational manner so that, collectively, we may find solutions to the problems that confront us all. It is a mark of our nation's maturity that we can openly and honestly discuss issues like these.

    Sir, indeed, over the last two days, my parliamentary colleagues have freely

Column: 2325

brought and frankly discussed numerous awkward and sensitive issues relating to race and religion. This attests to our confidence with the majority of Singaporeans with regard to such potentially divisive issues. It also reflects our beliefs in the strengths of our inter-racial ties which have been painstakingly and deliberately cultivated over the last three decades. It is an affirmation that the majority of Singaporeans believe in our multi-racial and multi-religious compact and that they are moderate in their practice of religion, not just Muslims, but Buddhists, Taoists, Christians, Hindus and others.

    As the Economist in its November-December 2002 issue aptly commented:

    'Secrecy and centralisation are useful watchwords in a conventional war .. But if the war against terrorism is going to last for years, the governments need to mobilise their people. The way to do that is to treat them as adults and give them as much information as possible without compromising sources of intelligence - even if this does cause a few sleepless nights.'

    Let me now offer my own perspectives on the responses we need to take to combat the terrorist threat. I suggest a four-pronged approach to JI, three of which echo what the White Paper proposes. The conceptual framework is that of a series of enlarging concentric circles, with widening application and impact. These are the four P's of pre-emption of terrorist strikes; propagation of Islamic truth; progression of the Malay/Muslim community; and promotion of inter-ethnic and religious harmony.

    Firstly, pre-emption of terrorist strikes. At the centre of the series of circles are the hard security measures we need to take to prevent and pre-empt terrorist strikes. We need to improve the security of key installations and targets. We need to tighten border controls. We need to choke off funds meant for financing terrorism. We need to have superior intelligence and surveillance against the "super-terrorism" we are facing. I am comforted that the Government has stated unequivocally in the White Paper that it has taken these

Column: 2326

steps and more to harden Singapore against terrorist infiltration and attacks.

    I urge the Government not to let up on these security measures as they give the population and investors alike assurance that Singapore is clearly among the safest destination in the region. Indeed, the international community working in Singapore viewed the arrests as evidence of an effective security apparatus that gives investors confidence in our country's ability to thwart all manner of threats.

    There have been murmurings about the long jams at the Tuas and Woodland Checkpoints. But I strongly feel, and I gather that many other Singaporeans also, that the strict border checks should not be relaxed. The resulting inconvenience is but a small price to pay for our social, economic and political security.

    However, our homeland security lattice, no matter how sophisticated, can only do so much, because the Al-Qaeda threat is global, and therefore the front against terrorism must likewise be global. Our neighbours, with some of whom we have occasional tiffs, are similarly victims of terrorist attacks.

    Sir, I hope that Southeast Asia nations will be able to put aside our differences to confront the common enemy that can wreak havoc on our very existence.

    Secondly, propagation of Islamic truth. It has been said that the war on terrorism is 95% ideological and only 5% military. There is a Chinese proverb that says, zhan cao chu gen. We need to remove the sinister roots from which the terrorist tree grows and cut off the supply of new recruits. We need a counter-propaganda, not of half-truth and twisted teachings that sowed the seeds of JI. We need to debunk the myth that "true" Islam equals fundamentalist and militant Islam. This will not be easy. Because, Islam, like Christianity, is by nature monotheistic, preaching one way to salvation. Fiery itinerant Islamic teachers and mullahs, if unchallenged and unfettered, may not be teaching the correct interpretation of their

Column: 2327

faith and, indeed, even mislead people into believing that jihad and martyrdom is the one-way ticket to heaven.

    Some influential western scholars, like Samuel Huntington, have taken a pessimistic view that Islamic teaching has no room for pluralism. Instead, Muslim communalism will grow and lead to inter-religious strife and eventual Balkanization, that is, disintegration of the nation state along religio-ethnic lines. That conception cannot and should not remain unchallenged by Muslims in Singapore. Otherwise, we risk the return to the dark days of communal strife and the undoing of what our founding fathers have fought so hard to accomplish - the establishment of a multi-racial, multi-religious Singapore. Therefore, the Malay/Muslim community must affirm the moderate non-sectarian nature of Islam and the nation-building role.

    I am pleased to note that, in recent days, shortly after the release of the JI White Paper, many religious leaders and organisations from the Muslim community have come forward to state their stand, and argue for self-governance, and to take the necessary steps to ensure that itinerant teachers and self-styled mullahs will not be permitted to propagate heretical teaching and poison the minds of our younger Muslims. I think this proactive, firm and united stand has done much to allay any anxieties and prejudices the non-Muslim community may have.

    Third, progression of the Malay/Muslim community. Sir, the White Paper has noted that the JI network in Singapore comprised generally people with average, or above average, intelligence, and who cannot be classified as being socially disadvantaged. Yet, one cannot deny that the risk of being influenced by the JI movement could be greater among the weaker members of the Malay/Muslim community.

    The large issue facing us then is how to bring further economic and social progress to this community, in particular, to the weaker members of the community, so that they do not feel left behind in

Column: 2328

this age of rapid gobalisation and technological change and, therefore, become easier prey to deviant teachers.

    Again, I am keenly aware of the sensitivity faced when we raise this question among our Muslim friends. My parliamentary colleague, Mr Shanmugam, has spoken of this on Monday. The reality is that each race has its share of members who lag behind their compatriots, economically and socially. Sir, I am not suggesting affirmative action. So, in this sense, I am not even mildly heretical. In fact, I do not think that affirmative action is necessary at all. This is because, as the Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs has noted, the Malay community in Singapore has, in many ways, made its mark in our society. It has also been making great strides in closing any gap with the other communities. For this reason, I think what is needed is for self-help groups, like Mendaki, to press on with their efforts, especially to raise the educational attainments and quality of life of the weaker members of the Malay/Muslim community, thus further uplifting and achieving higher overall averages for the community. Other self-help groups, such as CDAC and SINDA, could also work together with Mendaki towards this end, as an added, tangible sign of solidarity and unity among the different races.

    Fourth, promoting social and ethnic-religious harmony. At the largest circumference of the strategic framework for tackling JI is the need to enhance social harmony among the various ethnic and religious groups. Sir, the need to do so is really unquestionable. Social and religious harmony are seeds that must be sown in all areas of public life in Singapore - schools, workplaces and communities. The national schools, in particular, are undoubtedly the crucible for multi-racial living. We must teach our children to be colour blind, and celebrate harmony amidst diversity. More activities designed to promote racial and religious harmony should be planned. For instance, there could be more designated projects related to our cultural and religious diversity where students of different races are required to work together in groups.

Column: 2329



    We should encourage and create opportunities for students of different races to interact and make friends with each other from as young an age as possible; in fact, from pre-school.

    There is a need to watch out for the unwitting formation of enclaves in schools because groups of students may unconsciously clique and engage each other in a particular language, and thus could alienate students of other races, who may otherwise feel out of place.

    It is natural for people of the same colour to congregate. We do so overseas to gain a measure of security and for purposes of identification. But, doing so in Singapore, could also raise social barriers and hamper more meaningful inter-racial interaction. Certain sports, like basketball or sepak takraw, tend to attract participation from specific groups in schools. Without restricting choice, schools must make every effort to complement such propensities for specific groups to coalesce around certain sports and games, with other activities that have wider appeal to all races.

    At the community level, grassroots organisations and grassroots leaders must likewise be committed to the multi-racial ideal in planning activities.

    It is commonly observed that Malays are under represented in grassroots organisations. The non-Malay community, especially the Chinese majority, should redouble their efforts to reach out to the Malay community and make them feel comfortable. They would have to get rid of any residual practices and prejudices they may have, which may hinder Malays from joining the grassroots organisations and cause them to concentrate almost exclusively on their own mosque-based activities.

    For instance, though the incidence of this today could be considerably lower than before, I do hear of complaints from the non-Chinese community that

Column: 2330

some grassroots organisations still conduct their meetings in Chinese, without formally offering translations in the other languages. There are also complaints that some non-Muslim grassroots leaders still remain insensitive to the Muslim's food requirements at functions.

    These perceived prejudices, if unchecked, could drive a wedge between the Malay/Muslim community, already forced into an uncomfortable period of introspection by the JI events and the other races, especially the Chinese.

    Having Singaporeans of different races and religion dining together and visiting each other's places of worship is definitely a good start to greater understanding of the different races and religion. In fact, when I was in Florida last December, I read, with some satisfaction in the local newspaper, that in an attempt to imbue greater understanding about Americans of different religions, the Muslim organisations in Florida are initiating visits to different places of worship for Americans of all creed. However, attempts to foster greater understanding and confidence among the different races and religions clearly cannot stop at this rather symbolic and significant superficial level. Confidence and trust in a person can only be built when we get to know each other personally, and the best way to achieve this is through working with each other. Hence, at the community level, we must encourage more residents of different races and religions to come forward to work on community projects together.
